text: Framed in the large picture window stands JACK CARTER,  alone, looking out at the night. He turns away as the hea satin curtains close, wiping him from view.

A blinding beam of light cuts across the room. One  pornographic slide after another hits the screen at the  opposite end of the room. They show a dowdy group in some anonymous bedroom, frozen in various stages of a sexual  orgy.  GERALD FLETCHER is slumped on a sofa. His young wife, ANN is curled up beside him.  SID FLETCHER, operating the projector's remote-control,  has the same flaccid appearance as his twin brother.  Jack Carter, drink in hand, watches from an armchair.  Clunk. Another slide hits the screen. Gerald is getting  turned on. He runs his hand along his wife's stockinged  leg. Anna shudders momentarily. She obviously finds his  touch repulsive. Carter watches Gerald's hand.
(removing the cigar  from his mouth) Bollock naked with his socks still  on?
(thoughtfully) They do that up North.
What for? Protective purposes?
He laughs.
Ask me?
Ask Jack. It's his old stamping  ground.
Carter turns sharply away to the cocktail cabinet. Lights and sweet music happen when he opens it.  Clunk. The slide changes.
Must be a bloody contortionist
Still looking at the screen, Gerald continues.
We don't want you to go up the  North, Jack.
Jack and Anna look at each other momentarily. There is  definitely something between them.
No.
Clunk. The slide changes.
(groans) Not suede boots!
Knock it off, Gerald.
What? And get the clap?
Clunk. The slide changes.
You work for us, Jack. We have  connections in those parts.  I'd  hate you to screw 'em up.
Clunk. The slide changes.
What's that? A python.
Sid laughs raucously.  Clunk. The slide changes.
What are you going for?
To find out what happened.
Clunk. The slide changes.
Some hard nuts operate up there,  Jack. They won't take kindly to  someone from London poking his  bugle in.
Too bad.
I smell trouble, boy.
Clunk. The slide changes.
The law was satisfied.
Since when was that good enough?
Clunk. The slide changes.
Think again, Jack.
I will.
Express train plunges into a tunnel Blackness.
The compartment is full. Jack Carter sits in one corner,  reading a Raymond Chandler paperback, Farewell My Lovely.
The train speeds northwards. In the distance the stacks o a lonely power station belch a continuous stream of brown smoke.
Carter steadies himself as he comes along the corridor.
A massive iron bridge crossing a river whips past. Its  mesh sides create an almost hypnotic effect.
Carter tips his head back and dispenses drops into his  nose.
The train breaks from another tunnel. Evening light cuts  across the track as the train hurtles on.
Carter pours himself a glass of water and takes out a sma phial of brown pills. He swallows one.
A chemical factory, brightly lit, passes by and the  outskirts of the city appear.
The train moves slowly along the platform and stops. Cart collects his coat and briefcase from the rack.
The street is fairly deserted.   Carter exits with other passengers from the train. He pau and looks about before crossing to the pub opposite.
A couple of youths are playing records on the juke box. A old man sits in the corner reading a newspaper.   Carter enters through the swing door and a weedy BARMAN  comes to serve him.
Pint of bitter.
The barman picks up a glass mug and begins to draw the  beer. Carter snaps his fingers at him.
In a thin glass.
The barman sighs petulantly, transfers the beer into a  thin glass and puts it on the counter. A telephone rings. The second barman answers it.
Is there a Mr Carter in the room?
Yes.
Carter walks to the far end of the bar and picks up the  receiver.

Hello? (pause) Margaret? (pause) Why the hell aren't you here? (he lights a  cigarette.) What time? (pause) Is Doreen at the house? (pause) Who's with him then? (pause) When can I see you? Will you be  there tomorrow? (pause) Now listen, Margaret...
The line goes dead. Carter hangs up.

A key hanging inside the letter box starts to move upward and out through the flap. A moment later, the door opens. Carter is standing at the bottom of a flight of stairs in a worker's terraced house. He closes the door and climbs  the stairs.
Carter moves cautiously. His eyes scan the peeling  wallpaper, the mildew on the banisters. A roof leak hits  an unseen bucket with depressing regularity.

An unmade bed with pyjamas on it, a beaten-up wardrobe, a dressing table and chair are about it. Carter hears a  vehicle stopping on the street below. He eases back the  ancient net curtain. Two men in a Land Rover are looking  up. They see him and quickly drive off. Carter looks around the room. On top of the wardrobe ther an old shotgun. He reaches up and brings it down. Memorie flood back. He reaches up again and finds a box of  cartridges. More memories, jack and Frank grew up here. H leaves the gun on the bed and returns to the landing.

Pitch black. An overhead light snaps on to the face of a dead man FRAN CARTER. He is lying in a coffin. His eyes are closed, his skin made-up, like porcelain. Carter stands over the coffin. He gently touches his  brother's crossed hands and folds the shroud over his fac He exits, turning out the light and closing the door.  Darkness returns.
The landlady, EDNA GARFOOT, is climbing the stairs. She's well built, sexy, experienced. Carter follows with his  baggage. He watches her appreciatively from behind.
I won't be using the room tonight.
(stops and turns) I see.
I'm staying with a friend.
(continuing up the  stairs) Her husband docks tomorrow, does  he?
(smiles) It's not like that, luv.
It never is.
The door opens and the light goes on. It's a big room  overlooking the road, furnished cheaply but comfortably.  Edna and Carter enter, talking.
Are you a traveller?
(smiling) Definitely.
(surveying the room) Will this do?
(looking around) Very nice. (He takes his wallet  out.) I'll pay you for tonight as  well.
Don't be bloody silly. You're the  first since Monday.
You sure?
Carter gives her the money.
Ta.
(feeling the mattress) I'll bet this one's seen some  action.
Carter smiles and looks straight at her. Edna returns his look, dead pan.
I'll give you the key when you  come down.
She closes the door.
Carter moves around the coffin as he shaves. His electric razor is plugged into the lamp above his dead brother.
The coffin lid is being screwed down.   Carter stirs a cup of instant coffee while watching the  undertakers at work.
Was he in bad shape?
They come worse.

The hearse is parked outside the row of terraced houses. youthful UNDERTAKER is minding it. He turns and looks  through the back window as a young girl walks up the stre DOREEN CARTER is sixteen and, like most girls of her age, tries to look older. She wears all the right gear but it' cheap and doesn't fit properly. Her long hair is lank.   There's something sad and embarrassing about her appearan The young undertaker watches as she enters Frank's house.
The door opens slowly. Doreen stands there looking at the coffin. Carter sees her.
Doreen?
She seems mesmerized by what's going on.
All right, are you?
Doreen doesn 't answer.
Been staying with a friend?
Doreen nods. The undertaker coughs and thrusts another  screw into the coffin.
Sorry about your father.
(pause) Yeah.
Tell me, Doreen, did the police  say anything?
(dazed) They said he was drunk.

The young undertaker is still in the hearse listening to  the radio. In the driving mirror he sees the Land Rover  moving slowly tip the road. It stops by the house. Two me suss the scene and drive off.
How's school?
I left last year.
Oh, what you doing now?
Working at Woolworths.
That must be interesting.
Yes.
Carter and Doreen look at each other awkwardly.
What you going to do? Live with  Margaret?
Doreen looks at him nervously, shakes her head and fumble in her bag for a cigarette. Carter continues, slightly indignant.
Well, why won't you come with us  to South America? My fiancee won't  mind, (pause) Your dad would have wanted it.
The undertaker puts the final screw in.
(to colleague) Get Hughbert up, will you? (to Carter) We're ready now, sir.

The undertakers struggle with the coffin down the narrow  staircase into the street. Outside Carter and Doreen wait with two men. EDDIE APPLEYARD, a middle-aged man, is wear a shabby tweed suit, cap and black tie. KEITH LACEY is a  young barman who worked with Frank.
We weren't sure where it was taking  place, like.
Nice of you to come.
No. Frank was a good bloke.
He was that.
One of the best.

Through the windscreen of the following limousine Carter  can see his brother's coffin in the hearse as it moves  slowly through the streets of the city. Sitting in front  on fold-out seats are Eddie and Keith.
I couldn't believe it when I heard.   Carter is suddenly attentive.
What?
I mean, I was surprised when he  didn't turn up for work.  He was  always on time.
Did you work with him, Keith?
At the Half Moon.

(not to be left out) It's a bloody funny thing. You  know a bloke for six bloody years  and all the time he's as calm as  gentle Jesus... (pause) ...then he goes and does a thing  like that. (he shakes his head.) It's a bloody funny thing.
(quietly) Yeah. A bloody funny thing!

As the cortege drives into the crematorium, it passes the Land Rover parked outside. The same two men who passed  Frank's house are in it. A long and expensive-looking  funeral cortege passes out as they move up the driveway.

Carter, Doreen, Eddie and Keith are in the front pews fac the catafalque on which Frank's coffin rests. The vicar i already midway through the solemn words of the 'committal when a woman enters. The clunk of her high heels cuts  through the silence. Everybody looks round.
(whispering to Doreen) Is that Margaret?
Doreen nods. Frank's coffin sinks out of sight.

Two men in long grey coats wait in silence. The coffin  appears. Expertly, they take it and swing it on to a  trolley. They push it up the wide corridor towards the  furnace. One of the men starts whistling cheerfully.

MARGARET is thirtyish, blonde, attractive in a tarty kind of way.  Her heels are too high and she is wearing a chea pair of sunglasses. She walks quickly away, down the  cloisters, past the memorial tablets and urns.   Carter comes out of the chapel and sees her.
Margaret.
Margaret stops and looks round. Carter joins her.  I thou you weren't coming.
Changed me mind.

They face each other in silence. Margaret looks past Cart and sees Doreen watching them at the end of the cloisters She turns away and starts walking slowly. Carter moves  with her.  Margaret continues nervously.
Everyhing go off all right?
Fine... (pause) I want to talk to you.
What about?
Doreen.
Margaret stops in her tracks and looks back at Doreen.  She's still watching them.
(adamantly) She's nothing to do with me.
(puzzled) What do you mean? You've been  Frank's bird ever since her mother  cleared off. You're closer to her  than anyone.
(shaking her head) No. No. It's not like that. I've  got a husband, you know.
Margaret starts walking again, fast.   Carter catches hold of her arm and stops her.
Hold it!   Hold it! (looking her in the  eye) Who killed Frank, Margaret?
(nervously) Killed?  I don't know anything  about it.
She moves off rapidly. Carter catches up with her.
Really.
I must go. I'm in a hurry.
I want to talk to you later.
I can't.
Tomorrow morning, then?
Margaret dithers.
Well, all right then. Twelve o'clock  on the Iron Bridge.
Margaret walks off as calmly as she can, her high heels  clicking as she goes. Carter watches her disappear. Doree watches too.
Frank's coffin is slid inside the furnace. Flames start t lick it as the steel trap closes.

It's a large room with a horseshoe bar in the centre, a  real boozer.  A handful of hard drinkers are already in  position. Carter, Doreen, Keith and Eddie are sitting alone. Their  table is already covered with glasses. Doreen appears to  be slightly drunk on Babycham, Eddie on whisky and Keith  on beer. Carter is stone-cold sober.
Absent friends. (He raises his glass  and drinks, then  continues  thoughtfully.) You don't think he might have done  it on purpose?
What? You mean, like, kill himself?
Eddie and Keith look at each other. Doreen watches them. She is getting very upset by the  conversation.
Naw. Frank? Kill himself? You what?
Carter stares at Keith, who is getting uncomfortable.
I mean, what for?
That's what I was wondering.
Come off it. Frank was... well...  straight. He had no worries I know.  Hell, we worked together every day  for a year. It would have showed.
Why would it?
It just would. He was always the  same.
Since when did he drink whisky?
Don't know.
Nobody seems to know.
Doreen is now crying openly.
(finishing off his  drink) Bloody good bloke. One of the best.
(blurts out) How would you know? (She suddenly jumps  up and empties her  glass in Eddie's  face.) Or you?  Or you? None of you knew.   I knew. He was me dad.
She runs off out of the door crying. Keith goes to follow Carter puts his hand out to restrain him.
Let her go. She'll be OK. (to Eddie) Sorry about that.
(wiping his face  with a handkerchief) Don't worry. She's bound to be  upset.
(to Eddie) Have another?
No. I'll be off now. I should be  at work.
Eddie stands up, cap in hand. Carter pulls out a wad of  money.
Look, look. (He peels off a  note.) Get your suit cleaned.
No. It's all right.
(standing, pushes  the note in his  top pocket) Thanks for coming.
Frank was a good bloke. It's the  least I could have done.
Eddie leaves.
You work here, Keith?
Yes.
Carter thinks for a moment, then leans forward to Keith.
Keith, if anybody comes in here  and asks for me, you let me know.  Right?
Right.
I'm at the Las Vegas. Behind the  dance hall. (He casts an eye  around the bar.) Do you know a man called Albert  Swift?
Yeah. He comes in here a bit.
Where would I find him?
Today? At the races. He always  goes.
Carter takes out his phial of pills.
How'd you know Albert?
Went to school with him. (smiles) He was leader of our gang. He'll  know what's going on in this town.

The rain has just stopped. Bookies and punters lower thei umbrellas. Horses thunder towards the finishing post. Tur flies in all directions as the jockeys whip their mounts  in a last desperate effort and the crowd roars.

Albert Swift is standing by a bookmaker's marking bis rac card with a biro. A hot dog is sticking out of his mouth, like a cigar. A man of about thirty-five, be appears much older, probably from an excess of booze and women. He loo up, and his mouth drops open, the hot dog falling to the  ground. He has seen Carter.
Carter is pushing his way along the line of bookies, all  the time looking about him. The track loudspeaker announc the winner of the last race.
Albert pales. He holds his race card in front of his face and disappears into the crowd. As he moves off, his foot  steps on the hot dog and tomato ketchup oozes out.

Carter stands alone, casting an eye over the punters. His eyes rest on someone the other side of the saddling ring  ERIC PAICE.  Dressed in a grey chauffeur's uniform, cap,  dark glasses and gloves, he is standing close to three  well-heeled-looking men with binoculars and shooting stic Horses for the next race are being led around the enclosu Carter approaches from behind. He looks at Eric closely  before speaking.
Grey suits you, Eric.
Eric swings round, startled.
Good God!
Carter smiles.
Is he?
Jack Carter.
(amused) Eric. Eric Paice.
What you doing around here then?
Didn't you know this is my home  town?
No, I didn't know that.
Funny, that.
Carter takes out his cigarettes. Eric takes one.
Thanks. So what're you doing? On  your holidays?
No. I'm visiting relatives.
Oh, that's nice.
It would be. If they were still  living.
Meaning what?
A bereavement. A death in the  family.
Oh, I'm sorry to hear that.
That's all right, Eric.
Carter flicks bis lighter and gives Eric a, light.
Well, well. Small world, isn't it?
Very... (pause) So, who you working for these days  Eric?
Oh, I'm straight. (indicating uniform) Respectable.
(smiling) What are you doing? Advertising  Martini?
Oh, you've been watching television.
Yeah, (pause) Come off it, Eric. Who is it?
Eric smiles back.
Brumby?
Eric shakes his head.
Kinnear?
Eric shakes his head
What's it to you anyway?
I've always ad your welfare at  heart, Eric. Besides which, I'm  nosy.
That's not always a healthy way to  be...
And you should know, if I remember  rightly.
A track announcement interrupts them.
So you're doing all right then,  Eric. You're making good.
Making a living.

Good prospects for advancement, is  there? A pension? (He can't resist it  any longer. He  lifts the sunglasses  off Eric's nose  and looks into his  eyes.) Do you know, I'd almost forgotten  what your eyes looked like.
Eric stares back.
They're still the same. Piss holes  in the snow.
Still got a sense of humour?
Yes, I retained that, Eric. (He moves towards  the saddling ring  and turns to Eric.) Do you know a man called Albert  Swift, Eric?
Can't say I do.
Carter looks across at the track.
Don't miss the start on my account.
Starting gates slam open and the horses leap out.
Carter is driving along a country road. Ahead, two cars  are between him and a Cadillac with dark-tinted windows.  The Cadillac turns on to a minor road. Carter follows.
Eric Paice is driving. In the back sit the three men seen with him at the race track. The drinks compartment is ope and they are helping themselves to champagne. Racing resu come over the car radio.
Carter follows the Cadillac at a safe distance. It turns  into a driveway. Carter slows down and reads a sign by th entrance: The Heights.  He drives on and parks.

Carter comes through a wooded area. He pauses by a lake,  now overgrown with weeds. A big man stands tossing stones into the water. Carter silently picks up a dead branch  then runs at the man. Carter whacks him on the head and h collapses unconscious into the lake. Carter moves on towa the house. MARTY and RAY the two men previously seen in  the Land Rover, are playing with an Alsatian on the spaci lawn fronting the house. It's a Victorian building  surrounded by acres of woodland. Carter breaks from the trees and darts for the side door. One of the men notices and shouts after him.
Carter runs into the house and slips into a small service room. Ray and then Marty charge inside but miss seeing  Carter.

A game of poker is in progress. Seated around the table  are the three men with Eric at the race track. With them  is an elegant man, CYRIL KINNEAR. On the sofa are GLENDA, a sexy-looking young woman, and Eric Paice. Ray bursts in.
Carter's here.
Eric jumps up.
Where?
I don't know.
You stupid shit!
Carter walks past Ray, blowing him a kiss. Kinnear watches with some amusement.
You see what it's like these days,  Jack.  You can't get the material.
Carter looks at Eric.
Yes, I can see your problem, Mr  Kinnear.

Sit down, Jack, (pause) I could weep. I really could.   Sometimes I think I'll retire.  Just piss off to the Bahamas and  let somebody else employ them, (to girl) Glenda, get Jack a drink. What is  it, Jack?
(to Glenda) Scotch, please.
(to bouncer) Piss off, Ray.
Ray closes the door behind him. Glenda brings Carter his Scotch. He looks at her as she  sits beside him.
Eric told me of your bereavement.
Yep.
Do you know, I never knew he worked  in one of my places!
No? Funny that. Neither did I.
If I'd known, I'd have fixed him  up with something better.
Yeah.
Nasty way to go.
Yes.
One of the three men sitting around the table with Kinnea gets impatient. PETER, LES AND HARRY are well-heeled, mid aged, northern businessmen.
Are we here to play cards or talk  about the old days?

Harry! Jack, I don't want to be  rude, but these men have brought a  lot of money with them. Glenda,  you don't offer a man like Jack a  drink in those piddling little  glasses.  Give him the bloody  bottle. (He picks up his  cards.) Now, where are we?
Harry keeps a cold, wary eye on him.
Oh... I think I'll stay as I am.
(shaken) You're bluffing, you bastard!
That's what you pay to find out.  Right, Jack?
Right. If you can afford it.
(to Carter) Thought you were going soon.
Soon. When you've lost your money.  Won't take long.
Clever sod, aren't you?
Only comparatively.
Harry, I don't like to push, but  could you let us know how much  your hand's worth?
Harry looks at his cards. Glenda tucks her legs up, makin sure that Carter gets an eyeful.
You know Sid Fletcher?
What?
You know Sid Fletcher?
I work for him.
Do you?
(amused) Yes, I do.
Carter looks back at the table. Kinnear pushes in some  money.
What's that? A hundred?
That's right, Harry.
Your hundred, and another hundred.
Kinnear lays more cash on the table.
What's that?
That, Harry? That's another hundred -  twenty-five pounds notes of the  realm.
Three hundred altogether?
Three hundred altogether, Harry.
Glenda attracts Carter's attention again.
I know him too.
Who?
Sid Fletcher.
(sending her up) Oh, do you?
(dumb) Yes.
No, do you really?
Carter turns to the table yet again. Harry nervously puts another hundred on the table. Kinnea purses his lips.
I'll follow that and go two hundred.
Harry looks sick.
You can always see me, Harry.
Harry sweats and then smiles nervously.
All right. Two hundred.
(raises an eyebrow) Ha.
Kinnear takes a wad of notes out of his pocket. Glenda,  shifts herself on the sofa.
Yes. I met him last year.
Go on.
Oh yes. When he came up on business.
Really?
He came to see Mr Kinnear.
No.
Carter, getting bored, looks back at the game.
(panicking) What's that?
That's six hundred pounds, Harry.  Two hundred to follow you, and  I've raised it four hundred.
Harry sweats some more.
Four hundred?
That's right.
You're not seeing me?
No.
Harry smiles nervously. He counts some money out.
I'll see you, then.
Calling my bluff, are you, Harry?
Harry nods. Glenda speaks, but this time Carter keeps his eyes on the table. Kinnear lays out his hand  a hearts flush, queen  high.
We went about together.
Really?
Yes, while he was here.
While he was here. You went about  together?
He was here for four days.
Was he?
Could you do me a favour?
Yeah, I'll do you a favour.
Could you please put my glass on  the table?
Carter smiles and does just that.
Oh, come on, Harry. I haven't won,  have I? Go on, you're pulling my  leg.
Kinnear leans across to pick up Harry's cards. Harry grab them and puts them in the pack. Kinnear turns to Carter.
How about that, Jack?  Old Harry  thought I was having him on.
Shut up.
Carter gets up from the sofa.
Not going, Jack?
I have to. Things to see to.
Of course, of course. Well, any  time, just drop by.
Yeah, I'll do that. (He points at Harry.) Told you it wouldn't take long,  didn't I?
Eric opens the door and follows him out.
Carter moves towards the front door.
Jack! I didn't like that.
You should have told me who you  were working for.
Cyril didn't like it, either.
Oh, Cyril, eh? So it's all girls  together, is it?
He's thinking Sid and Gerald won't  like it much when they hear you've  been sticking your nose in.
Carter carries on walking to the front door. He opens it.
He's right. Tell him to save the  cost of the phone call.
Carter leaves. Eric signals Ray to follow him.

Huge metal claw catches hold of an old car and lifts it  like it was a toy. The yard is beside the River Tyne. In  the distance a train crosses the Iron Bridge. Carter is examining a beaten-up Hillman when the yard own BILLY LAWS, approaches.
(suspicious) What do you want?
What happened to this car?
What's it got to do with you?
This is my brother's car.
Oh ay?
Yeah.
Well, he drove it into the river.
Was the steering faulty?
Billy shakes his head.
What about the brakes?
Fine. Nowt wrong with them.
How'd it happen, then?
He was drunk. Drunk as a lord.
Was he?

A big, busty pub singer is performing on the small stage. A trio on her right plays a good, grinding, up-tempo numb Carter comes through the door. He pushes his way through  the packed drunken crowd to the bar. Keith serves him.
What you having, Jack?
Large Scotch.
Carter watches the singer. The customers cheer and whistl Keith returns with the Scotch. He looks nervously around  and speaks to Carter quietly.
Heard of a man called Thorpe?
Old Thorpey? Haven't seen him in a  long time.
(picking up Carter's  money) That's what he was saying about  you.
Keith takes the money to the till. The music grinds away. Keith returns.
Said he'd heard you were up in  town. Wondered if I knew where you  was staying. Wanted to look you  up. Old time's sake.
That's nice. What'd you tell him?
Nowt.
Good lad.
Carter watches the singer, then finishes his drink.
See you later.
Where you off to?
(smiling) Las Vegas.

Carter makes for the door. The singer is now moving throu the tables. She pauses to give some man a kiss. Everybody cheers. The woman sitting with the man snaps. She picks up his  glass of beer and throws it over the singer; then grabs  her hair and pulls her to the ground. Carter stops to watch. The two women roll on the floor,  punching and scratching. Carter smiles and leaves.

On the corner is a neon-lit snack bar. Doreen and another young girl are sitting inside sucking milk shakes. Somewh a drunk is singing. His voice echoes up the alley. Carter draws alongside and notices Doreen. He stops and  watches her. She hasn't seen him so he goes to the window and knocks on it. She looks up and he beckons her outside Reluctantly, she comes.
(gently) You all right now?
Yeah.
You coming to South America?
No.
Carter's hurt and slightly irritated by this rejection.
Where you going to live, then?
At me friend's house.
Where's that?
Wilton Estate.
Nice family, are they? Church-goers  and all that?
Doreen nods.
Good. I'm off tomorrow, so I don't  suppose I'll see you again. (He pulls out a wad  of money, and peels  off some notes.) There. Go and get your hair done.
(Can't believe it) Thanks.
He lifts her chin with his finger and looks at her.
Be good. And don't trust boys.
Doreen blushes and turns away. She rushes back to the sna bar with the money to show her friend.
The front door opens and Carter enters. Standing on the hall table is a small wooden casket with  an envelope taped to it. Carter pockets the envelope and  picks up the casket.
That was left for you this evening.
Carter walks past her into the sitting room.
What is it?
My brother, Frank.
Is he staying the night?
Funny. (He puts the casket  on a side table.) Can I phone London?
It'll cost you.

Anna is undressing. She's alone. Pulling the short black- silk underslip over her head, she stands in front of a  long mirror, clad only in black panties, bra and tights.  She looks at herself appreciatively. The phone rings. She flops on the bed and picks up the receiver.
Hello.
A voice speaks on the end of the line.
How I miss you. (She stretches  herself out sexily  and smiles.) Stop it, darling.
It's a cosy room. Carter is on the telephone. EDNA sits i a rocking chair.
(looking at Edna) I fancy you. I wish I was touching  you right now...
Edna turns towards him. Carter fixes her with his eyes.  Edna rocks herself gently. Carter continues softly.
...making love to you. I want to  stroke you and kiss you all over.  Where are you?
Anna is lying full-length on the bed.
In the bedroom.
Carter speaks on the other end.
My black underwear.
Edna rocks backwards and forwards.
(quietly) The sexy, silk ones?
Anna replies. He continues softly.
Take your bra off. (pause) No, go on.
Anna unhooks her bra. There's a flash of breasts.
The scene as before.
Now hold them. Gently.
Anna's hands cover her breasts. Her head moves slowly fro side to side, eyes closed.
Scene as before.
Slowly. Imagine it's me.

A wide road runs alongside the Tyne. It passes below the  vast steel bridges that link the two parts of the city. A carpark lies at the foot of the 'Iron Bridge'. Carter pul up and parks. He gets out and moves quickly.

(angrily) Look, I'm me, right. You're not.  We are what we are, like it or  not. (She turns and walks  slowly along the  bridge.) Why all the bloody needle?

Glenda pushes him away and gets out of the bed.
You bastard.

Glenda leaves for the bathroom. Carter, curious, looks at the film projector. It's loaded. He switches it on. A bea of light hits the opposite wall. He settles down to watch the film. The leader flashes by, then a title being chalk on a school blackboard 'The Teacher's Pet'.  A zoom back  reveals Glenda, bare-breasted, holding the chalk. This is followed by a long shot of a young girl, dressed in schoo uniform, waiting at a bus stop. A car approaches and stop A woman driver offers the girl a lift. The woman is  Margaret. The identity of the girl not revealed.
Glenda is in the bath. Lots of foam. The hot water is sti running.  She's smoking. She leans forward, turning off  the tap.

Carter is sitting up on the mattress, amused by the soft  porn unfolding on the white wall in front of him. The schoolgirl accepts the lift and the car drives off.  The door to an anonymous apartment opens and Margaret com in with the girl. Her school hat still hides her identity Glenda is there to greet them. The girl is very awkward. Glenda tries to make her relax, sitting her down and showing her a magazine. Glenda brings her into a bedroom. She takes her own top  off and goes to do the same with the girl. She takes her  hat off. A close-up shows that it is Doreen. Carter tenses but never flinches from what's happening in the film.  Margaret comes into the bedroom and feigns sho at what she sees. She slaps Glenda and they start fightin eventually rolling off the bed. The apartment door opens and a man smoking a big cigar  comes in. Carter sits up. It's Albert Swift. Albert opens another door, looking for someone. He leaves Another door opens and he's in the bedroom. He sees the  two women fighting on the floor, but on the bed is his  prize Doreen.  Carter watches. Doreen bites her nails and looks terrified. Reflected in  the mirror behind Carter is the image of Albert taking of his trousers. The reel runs out and flaps like a fish.  Carter doesn't move. Tears form in his eyes. He looks old and defeated. His is a wasted life. Then the anger that  drives him explodes again and he throws back the bedcloth
Carter, now dressed, moves slowly towards her in the bath
I want to give you an Oscar.
(laughs) You've been watching the film.
Tell me about the girl.
What girl?
The young girl. Who pulled her?
I don't know.
Was it Albert?
Shouldn't think so.
Is it one of Kinnear's films?
Yeah.
Who set it up?  Eric?
Yeah.
Then he must have pulled her.
Expect so.
Did my brother Frank find out?
Your brother? What you talking  about?
Carter's fury bursts. He's out of control. He seizes Glen and plunges her under the bathwater, holding her there.
You're a lying bitch.
Carter lifts her up, out of the water. She is spluttering nearly drowned.
Now tell me the truth.
The girl's name was Doreen. That's  all I know.
And you didn't know her last name?
No.
Well, it's Carter. That's my name, (pause) And her father was my brother. And  he was murdered last Sunday. Now  get up and get dressed.
He pushes her ahead of him.
Carter manhandles Glenda towards her Sunbeam. He opens th boot.
Get in.
Glenda climbs in and he slams the boot shut. The car  scorches away.
Carter parks the sports car as the ferry docks. He moves  down the gangway towards it.
A girl with a baby in a pram is having a cup of tea. The  door slams open. There's Carter.
Where's Albert?
The girl is numb with fear, unable to answer. Carter grab her by the throat.
Where's Albert?
The girl is frozen with terror. He lets go as suddenly as he grabbed her.
I know where I'll find him.
Carter walks fast. There's the sound of a phone being  dialled. It's the GIRL in the cafe.
Eric, he's come for Albert, (pause) I don't know, (pause) On the ferry,  I reckon.
Carter reaches the front of a betting shop. He walks in.
Carter closes the door. Race results and odds are coming  over the Tannoy. He moves into the shop until he reaches  ALBERT SWIFT. Albert is making out a betting slip and  doesn't see him.
Hello, Albert.
Albert looks like he's going to be sick.
Hello, Jack, (snivelling) I don't know anything, Jack.
Yes, you do, Albert. Talk or I'll  kill you.
I know. I know.
Carter sees a door at the back. There's a sign for the  toilets.
Do you want to go to the toilet,  Albert?
At first Albert doesn't understand.
Do you want to go to the toilet,  Albert?
This time it clicks. Albert moves to the door and Carter  follows.
Carter turns to close the door. Albert runs for it. He  reaches the high double-gate at the end. It's locked and  he tries to climb it. No luck. Carter easily pulls him  down. Albert faces him.
You can't get away from me, Albert.
I know.
He feels for his cigarettes but can't find them.
For Christ's sake, give us a fag.
Carter takes out his cigarettes. Albert takes one.
I didn't know who Doreen was.  Thought she was just another bird.
Did Eric Pake pull her?
Yes.
How?
I dunno. He's got his ways. He  knows Margaret.
When did you find out?
A couple of weeks back.
How?
No choice. I had a visit from  somebody.
Who?
Cliff Brumby. He'd seen the film.  He wanted to meet Doreen.
And you told Brumby?
Albert nods.
Who killed Frank?
Albert doesn 't answer.
Do you want to be dead, Albert?

Last Sunday afternoon, Eric and  two of his boys arrive with Frank  and tell me that he's rumbled.  Somehow, he's seen the film and  was about to shoot his mouth off.  They ask me for some whisky and  start forcing it down his throat. (pause) I thought they'd just duff him up  a bit. Honest.
What did you do?  Albert?
Nothing. What could I do?
Did Eric know that Frank was my  brother?
Yes. I told him.
What did he say?
'Good.'
Albert draws deeply on his cigarette. They drove Frank away in a car.
Is that all there is?
Albert nods.
Then that's it, Albert.
Carter takes something from his pocket. There's a loud  click.  It's a. knife.
Jack, for Christ's sake ...
He falls to his knees.
You knew what I'd do.
(crying) Yes, but listen. Christ, I didn't  kill him.
Carter drives the knife into him with all his might.
I know you didn't kill him. (and again.) I know you didn't.
A ship's horn calls mournfully from the harbour. Albert  leans back. Blood seeps from his chest. He pitches forwar twitches, and is dead.
Carter comes in from the back and walks calmly through to the street. A blind man is at the counter placing a bet.
The Sunbeam waits in the car park. Eric, Con and Peter  arrive in the Land Rover and park behind it. They go down the gangplank to the floating jetty. A ferry is chugging  across the water.
Carter sits, watching the other passengers. A mother and  two young children take his attention. His look is tinted with regret even remorse.

As the ferry comes alongside, Eric, Con and Peter move up to the rail. The passengers disembark, leaving Carter  standing alone.  He's holding Con's handgun. Eric, Con and Peter hack slowly away to the steel shelter Peter, impatient as ever, pulls a sawn-off automatic shoo from under his coat, cocks it and fires. Too late. Carter is already safely behind the ferry's superstructure. Eric shouts.
No shooters. Cyril said no shooters,  you stupid bastard.
Get stuffed.  He's reloading.
Gerald wants to see him first.
Shut up.
Carter is listening to all this.
(shouting) Are you coming in? Or do we piss  about all day?
Eric laughs.
You're finished, Jack. You know  that, don't you? I've bloody  finished you.
Not till I'm dead, Eric.
Eric laughs.
Oh, you've still got your sense of  humour?  Tell him how I've fixed  him, Con.
He's told Gerald about you and  Anna.
Didn't believe us at first, did  he, Con? Then Peter talked to him.
Didn't even say goodbye. Just asked  us to take you back - alive.
He's probably talking to her right  now. Are you still going to fancy  her when Gerald's finished with  her face?

Carter shows no emotion. Or are his eyes just that bit  sadder?  Peter lets rip again. Another window is shattere Carter ducks back, allowing Peter time to board the ferry Carter catches a glimpse of Peter as he climbs up the  ferry's superstructure to the roof. By the time he heaves himself into position, Carter is waiting.
Stay where you are, Peter.
Peter is helpless, clinging to the roof, unable to even  raise his shooter.
(screaming) Don't.

There's a long pause while Carter looks at him, then he  cold-bloodedly shoots. Peter is blown away. By the time h hits the deck, he's dead.   Con and Eric panic. They run up the gangplank, safely out of range.
Carter, your car needs a wash.

Eric signals to the driver in the Land Rover to bump the  Sunbeam into the water. Two hits and the task is done.   Glenda's screams are lost as the river wraps itself aroun the sinking car. Carter watches impassively.
Carter's hire car corners at speed into the high-rise  carpark.
Brumby and two architects in a site meeting. Plans are  laid out on a table.
I don't want them cooking in here.  You can put a hatch in that wall.
Yes, it's all a question of ...
The sound of a car screeching up the ramps interrupts him
Who in Christ's name is that? It's  a bloody madman.
He strides away to investigate.
Brumby comes out to the top tier. On the floor below,  Carter, unseen by Brumby, has parked and is now making fo the concrete spiral staircase.
Brumby pounds down to the first level. Carter comes aroun the corner.
Jack!
Carter slams his fist hard into his gut.
You shouldn't have shown the film  to Frank.
I had to. It was the only way I  could get at them.
It's a combined shop and post office. Carter is on the  phone.
The guy on the swing-bridge? (pause) OK.
Carter hangs up. He takes a can of film from his pocket  and slips it into a large envelope.  At the counter two  women are talking.
They don't know how it happened.
How far did he fall?
What did Betty say... Ninety floors,  I think it was.
Really. Was he dead?
Oh, yes.
The envelope is passed across to the post office assistan It is addressed to Vice Squad, Scotland Yard, London Sw1.
Better to go quick like that.

The huge steel superstructure pivots on a large man-made  island in the middle of the river. On top is a structure not unlike a small lighthouse, from which a man operates the bridge. Carter climbs the outsid ladder. A man waits for him at the top. The man hands him a small cloth package. Carter opens it. Inside is heroin and a hypodermic. He wraps it up again  and hands over an envelope. The man checks the money as  Carter disappears down the outside ladder.

The hall is crowded. The compere calls the numbers. The  atmosphere is tense as the audience look at their cards.  Someone calls, 'Bingo.' A buzz goes round the hall as  everybody starts talking again. Carter enters, surveying the audience. Eventually, his  eyes alight on the person he's been looking for Margaret. She's involved with a woman friend and doesn't see him.  The next game starts up.
Crowds of people come pouring out. It's the end of the  evening's entertainment. Margaret walks out with her frie Carter follows them and turns up a side street.

The place is deserted. Margaret and her friend descend th steps. The clop of their high heels is the only sound.  Carter follows discreetly. At the bottom, Margaret and he friend chat for a moment and part. Carter follows Margaret.

The clop of Margaret's shoes is heard in the distance. Sh appears. Carter is following behind. He slips into anothe dark alley to get ahead of her. As she reaches her home  Carter's arm shoots out from behind a pillar. It's holdin Con's handgun.
I've come for you, Margaret.

There's a big party going on. The music is loud. It's mai rich-looking middle-aged men and young dolly birds.  Different things are obviously going on in different room in the house. Dancing in one room, blue movies in another etc. Kinnear flits from one to another. Eric Paice is on  the phone. He puts the receiver down and crosses to Kinne
Gerald Fletcher wants a word with  you Cyril.
Kinnear crosses to the telephone.
Hello, Gerald.
Carter stands in the dimly lit kiosk with Margaret. The  hire car is parked alongside.
It's Carter. Listen carefully, you  hairy-faced git. I've got the film  and enough evidence to put you  away for a long time. All it takes  is one call to the police.
Kinnear listens.
Really? (pause) So?
Carter into phone.
I'll do a simple deal with you.  All I want is ...
Kinnear is still listening to Carter. He looks over at  Eric, who's fixing a drink.
I see. I think that can be arranged.
Kinnear continues listening.
Carter into phone.
... but I don't want him there  until six in the morning.  OK? (pause) Right.
Carter hangs up. He pushes Margaret towards the car.
The noise of the wild party is heard off. Eric comes into the room.
You want something, Cyril?
Yes, Eric. A word with you.
Headlights, through the thick trees, as Carter's car come bouncing over rough ground.
Carter stops in a clearing and leaves his headlights on.  He turns to Margaret.
Get out.
Carter and Margaret get out. They appear in the beam of  the headlights and move further into the wood.
Carter and Margaret stop.
Take your clothes off.
Margaret is confused.  Take your clothes off.  Margaret  does just that: coat, blouse, skin. She goes to remove he knickers.
Keep your pants on. (pause) Lie down.

Again she obeys. He kneels on her, pinning her arms with his knees, then  stuffs a gag in her mouth. He takes out the hypodermic, places it against her arm,  and injects the heroin into her. She struggles, her eyes  moving frantically about. She screams, but its muffled by the gag.  Carter holds her down and she quickly goes unde Carter removes the gag. He stands, picks her up and walks into the darkness with Margaret in his arms.
Kinnear is alone, speaking on the telephone quietly. The  party is still going on.
I want you to listen very carefully.  Jack Carter, (pause) You know what he looks like?
A bedside light is on. A man in bed is listening on the  phone.
Yes.

He taps his cigarette against the ashtray. On his middle  finger is a large ring with the initial 'J' on it. He  listens until the line goes dead. The woman beside him stirs. He stubs out the cigarette an switches off the light. Darkness.
Eric comes out of the front door. Inside the party is sti in progress. He gets into a Cadillac and drives off.
Carter is parked where he can see the drive up to Kinnear house. The Cadillac appears and swings on to the road. There's the sound of a phone being dialled.
Police.

A long line of police cars move slowly up the drive,  followed by a police bus. They park by the front door and around fifty policemen pour out. They move silently aroun the building. A chief constable opens the front door and  walks in.

The police move through the house and grounds. In the  bedrooms they find groups of people in bed together. The  men in particular protest and are obviously concerned abo being identified. The police find evidence of drugs,  pornography and so on. Outside, police are combing the grounds. In the long gras leading down to the lake they find women's clothes. They  follow the trail until they discover a woman floating nak face downwards, in the lake. A policeman with waders goes in and pulls her to the side. As others heave her out, we see that it's Margaret.

The house is surrounded by police measuring and  photographing, and outside the house are police cars and  ambulances.  The lawn is crowded with the party crowd. In the early-morning light, they look like dolls. Kinnear comes out of the front door with two plain-clothe officers and gets in a police car. Sirens going, it comes down the short drive to the gate.

Carter is driving along a coast road. The sea and a wide  beach lie on his right. Long rows of houses are to his  left. The sun is still low. It's very quiet. He arrives at a  harbour and drives on until he reaches the end of a vast  wooden jetty running out into the estuary. It's a coal  loader for tankers. This jetty is very high, a complex of wooden staves and  pillars, interwoven with steps and gangways. On its top  tier is a complex of railway lines, signals and black coa chutes.

Carter parks his car and picks up the shotgun and a bottl of Scotch off the back seat. He get out and walks over to the jetty and along a lower gangway. At the far end, a ma is standing. It's Eric Paice. Eric turns around abruptly. He sees Carter and disappears up the nearest stairway.  Carter follows. At the top he stops to listen, but can see and hear only  the harbour waters lapping below. Carter looks back to the coal jetty, just in time to see  Eric scamper down to the level below. Eric sprints for th roadway. Carter waits and then starts running directly  above him. Eric keeps running. Carter stays always overhead. He's  playing cat and mouse with Eric.
(calling out) You couldn't win an egg and spoon  race, Eric.
(wheezing) Sod off.

Paice darts down another staircase to ground level and  makes for the roadway. Carter stops above the roadway.  Below, Paice makes for the parked car. Carter holds the  gun up. Eric stops and looks up.
Stay away from the car or I'll  blow you apart.
Eric darts under the jetty. Carter runs on down the steps He can see Eric scampering along the row of cottages towa the beach. Carter starts after him.

Eric runs out on to the beach. The only sounds are his  feet pounding the pebbles and his hurtful panting. In the distance, factory chimneys belch out smoke.  Carte appears. For a moment he watches Eric stumbling along at  the far end of the beach. He climbs down to the beach and starts running.
Carter is gaining on Eric rapidly. Eric looks round and  panics. He stumbles and falls over. He gets to his feet quickly and disappears round the  headland. Carter follows.

On the other side of the headland, the scene is  extraordinary. The deserted beach is like the edge of the world. The sand is black as far as the eye can see. It's  littered with rubbish. Several old lorries are sunk deep  in the sand. High, grass-covered cliffs flank it on the  left. It's deserted. In the distance, a continuous line of giant black buckets move, like cable-cars, out to sea, before they deposit  their load of coal slag and move inland again. The coal  mine itself is inland, hidden away behind the cliffs. The sea, like the sand, is black as it crashes on to the shor Eric is half-way along the beach, struggling in the mud.  Carter closes on him.

Eric nears the line of buckets and cuts inland towards th mine.  Carter has nearly caught up. The buckets grind and crash as they move along the cable. Eric scrambles up the narrow valley down which the coal  slag travels. He is panting horribly. Carter is close on  his heels.  Near the top, where the buckets are practical at ground level, Eric stumbles and falls. He is too  exhausted to get up. Carter stands over him.
(panting slightly) Stand up, Eric. Stand up.
Eric just manages it. Carter pulls the bottle of Scotch  out of his pocket.
I bet you could use a drink, could  you, Eric?
He throws the bottle to Eric.
Eh? Have a drink.
Still got your sense of humour.
Eric takes the cap off and looks at Carter. He's in a  terrible state.
Drink up, Eric. Drink up. I want  you to drink all of that. Do you  understand? Drink up. Just like it  was with my brother, Frank. Go on,  son. Drink up.
Eric pours the whisky into his month. It spills over and  runs down his face.
Drink up, Eric.
Eric begins to stagger about.
It was you who poured it down him.  Eh, Eric?
Eric takes a breather and looks pathetically at Carter. N mercy there.
Did you all have a good laugh, eh?  Did you have a good laugh when he  was spewing it up? The whisky is  pouring all over Eric's face and  suit.
It's disgusting to watch. Suddenly, he retches, but nothi comes up.
Drink it! Drink it! Did you all  pass the bottle round after the  car went over the top?
Eric is choking.
Don't stop, Eric.
Carter leans forward and with his free hand lifts the bot up to Eric's mouth again. In the other, he holds the  shotgun.  Eric chokes and retches. Carter has seen enough
Goodbye, Eric.
Carter raises the butt of the gun and brings it down on  Eric's head.

Eric's body, loaded on to a a coal bucket, moves off on  it's final journey. Carter, laughing, walks beside it, gu riding on his shoulder. The bucket shudders and grinds as it moves along the cable. Eric's body moves of on its fin journey. It reaches the end of the line, where an automat catch tilts it. Eric's body drops into the sea. The coal  slag follows in a cloud of black dust. The waves pass ove and everything is gone. Carter stands for a moment, turns and walks back along th beach. He stops, looks at the shotgun, and decides to get rid of it.

Below, Carter moves slowly by the edge of the sea. He rai the shotgun to throw it away. High on the clifftop a rifl and telescopic lens line up on Carter. A finger curls aro the trigger. On the middle finger of the same hand is a  large gold ring with the letter 'J' engraved upon it. It  is the man Kinnear contacted after sending Eric to his  death.  The finger tightens on the trigger and pulls it. There's quiet, whooshing sound. Carter drops to the ground.
Carter lies on the beach. The waves lap around his head. small trickle of blood pours out of a hole in his temple. He's dead.
Kinnear's hit man coolly dismantles his rifle. He careful wraps it in a cloth fishing-rod carrier. He walks off and is soon lost as he drops out of sight.
